list.title: Question 1
list.content: The organisms in the table below all share a common ancestor.OrganismVertebraeTwo pairs of limbsSweat GlandsTroutPresentAbsentAbsentBlack bearPresentPresentAbsentHumanPresentPresentPresentUse the data in the table to draw a cladogram.[2]State the source of variation which allowed organisms in the cladogram to diverge into different species[1]In cladistics, state the name used to describe a group of organisms which have all evolved from a common ancestor.[1]
list.markScheme:
Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​a node for a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms in the correct order (trout, black bear, human)[1][2 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/44ad43f9-26fa-4810-80af-e45631739993/images/a702b776-b79e-4f55-8a6c-2b7ca3b3f99f/273ai.png)

Onlynames of organisms expected, features added just for explanation.→\ce{ -> }​mutations[1][1 mark maximum]→\ce{ -> }​clade[1][1 mark maximum]

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which of the following statements is the correct definition of evolution?A.\hspace{1em}Heritable characteristics of a species change over time.B.\hspace{1em}Organisms are reproductively isolated.C.\hspace{1em}Learned behaviours change over time.D.\hspace{1em}Organisms are bred for desired characteristics.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Evolution is the change in the characteristics of a population over time; these characteristics can be passed from one generation to another (Choice A).Choice Bis incorrect as it describes when organisms are reproductively isolated, which is a mechanism that may lead to evolution in a population.Choice Cis incorrect because it refers to learned behaviours which are learned within an organism’s lifetime and are not genetically inherited.Choice Dis incorrect as it refers to selective breeding.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: What evidence can be, and has been used, to determine the members of the same clade?I.\hspace{1em}Base sequence of genesII.\hspace{.7em}Amino acid sequence of proteinsIII.\hspace{.4em}Physical appearance of organismsA.\hspace{1em}II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and IIC.\hspace{1em}II and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice D is correct.
The DNA sequence (Statement I) and amino acid sequence (Statement II) are the usual, present way of determining members of the same clade, however, physical appearance (Statement III) was previously, but is now rarely, used.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: In cladistics, which is the correct definition of a clade?A.\hspace{1em}A group of organisms with the same DNA sequenceB.\hspace{1em}A group of organisms that share a common ancestorC.\hspace{1em}A group of organisms with different DNA sequencesD.\hspace{1em}A group of organisms that do not share a common ancestor
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis the correct definition for a clade, a group of organisms that share a common ancestor.Choice AandCare incorrect as they do not feature the idea of a common ancestor.Choice Dis incorrect because organisms within a clade do share a common ancestor.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: According to natural classification, organisms in the same group had what in common?A.\hspace{1em}MorphologyB.\hspace{1em}Anatomical characteristicC.\hspace{1em}Modes of nutritionD.\hspace{1em}Common ancestry
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because organisms placed in the same group share common ancestry.Choice AandChoice Bare incorrect because morphology and anatomical characteristics are used to describe the structures of organisms which are used to primarily group them together.Choice Cis incorrect because modes of nutrition are used to describe organisms but not to classify organisms.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: To which domain do organisms with membrane-enclosed organelles belong to?A.\hspace{1em}EukaryotaB.\hspace{1em}ArchaeaC.\hspace{1em}EubacteriaD.\hspace{1em}Prokaryotes
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because Eukaryota are the only group with nuclei and membrane-bound organelles.Choice Bandchoice Care incorrect because organisms in these two domains (Archaea and Eubacteria) do not have membrane-enclosed organelles.Choice Dis incorrect because prokaryotes are not the name of a domain.

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Which technique estimates the divergence time between species based on genetic differences?A.\hspace{1em}Radioactive datingB.\hspace{1em}Molecular clock datingC.\hspace{1em}Comparative anatomyD.\hspace{1em}Studying fossil layers
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Molecular clock dating uses the genetic differences between species to estimate their times of divergence. This method relies on the assumption that mutations accumulate at a relatively constant rate over time. By comparing the DNA sequences of different organisms, scientists can estimate how long ago their last common ancestor lived.Choice Bis, therefore, correct.Radioactive dating is a method used to date rocks and other materials based on the known decay rates of radioactive isotopes.Choice Ais, therefore, not correct.Comparative anatomy involves comparing the structures of different organisms to understand their evolutionary relationships. While it can provide evidence of common ancestry and evolutionary trends, it does not offer a precise method for estimating the time of divergence between species based on genetic differences.Choice Cis, therefore, not correct.Studying the distribution of fossils within sedimentary rock layers establishes relative ages and the chronological order of geological and evolutionary events. Whilst it is essential for constructing the timeline of life on Earth, it does not use genetic differences to estimate divergence times between species.Choice Dis, therefore, not correct.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Which taxonomic group of organisms represents a domain?A.\hspace{1em}EukaryotaB.\hspace{1em}PlantaeC.\hspace{1em}ProtoctistaD.\hspace{1em}Animalia
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Eukaryota is one of only three domains - the other two being Archaea and Eubacteria.Choice B(Plantae) is one of the five kingdoms, not a domain.Choice C(Protoctista) andChoice D(Animalia) are also kingdoms.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Which of the following represents the correct order for the traditional taxonomic hierarchy?A.\hspace{1em}Class→\rightarrow→Order→\rightarrow→FamilyB.\hspace{1em}Phylum→\rightarrow→Order→\rightarrow→ClassC.\hspace{1em}Order→\rightarrow→Genus→\rightarrow→FamilyD.\hspace{1em}Kingdom→\rightarrow→Order→\rightarrow→Phylum
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because the traditional hierarchy of taxa is a domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, so class→\rightarrow→order→\rightarrow→family is in the correct order.Choice Bis incorrect because the class is above order.Choice Cis incorrect because the family is above genus.Choice Dis incorrect because the phylum is above order.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: In a cladogram, what is represented by a node?A.\hspace{1em}A new trait that is shared by two organismsB.\hspace{1em}The most recent common ancestor between speciesC.\hspace{1em}A group of organisms with a common ancestorD.\hspace{1em}The most genetically distant organisms
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Nodes on a cladogram are a splitting point that represent the most recent ancestor between species;Choice Bis correct.A node does not represent a new trait shared by two organisms;Choice Ais incorrect. A group of organisms with a common ancestor is a clade, not a node;Choice Cis incorrect. The most genetically distant organism on a cladogram is an outgroup, not a node;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Which arrow correctly identifies a node in the cladogram?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/69c93911-093d-43fa-b75c-1769ca9016d1/images/c793b196-2c02-4fd1-91e0-0de4b74073d4/BI0266%20primate%20cladogram%20i.png)

[Adapted from: Source Bockman, P. (2011, October 3).File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https:// commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A node is the point where species diverge.Choice Dis correct.Choices AandBare incorrect as they point to the middle of the line, so they do not represent divergence.Choice Cis incorrect as it points to a species.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
According to the cladogram, which two primates are the most closely related?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/008ac188-a233-4bb5-b8bb-1f6a59da105e/images/1afb59aa-b10a-4467-b0d5-c7f223838826/BI0263.png)

[Adapted from: Source Bockman, P. (2011, October 3).File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https:// commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]A.\hspace{1em}New world monkeys and old world monkeysB.\hspace{1em}Lorises and lemursC.\hspace{1em}Lemurs and humansD.\hspace{1em}Apes and humans
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Humans and apes (Choice D) are the most closely related because they shared a common ancestor more recently than the other primates, such as new world and old world monkeys (Choice A), Lorises and Lemurs (Choice B) and Lemurs and Humans (Choice C).

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
The diagram below represents the three domains of life.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/292dca29-d444-488e-b4ca-9141aee0f532/images/921a7728-af80-441f-a1f0-9779a836ac28/BI0251ii.png)

[ © Revision Village 2022]Which row has the correct names for the domains?Domain 1Domain 2Domain 3\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}ArchaeaProkaryotesEukaryote\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}ProtistaProkaryotaEukaryota\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}ProtistaEubacteriaEukaryota\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}EubacteriaArchaeaEukaryota
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because the three domains of organisms are Archaea, Eubacteria and Eukaryota.Choice Ais incorrect because prokaryote is not the name of one of the domains.Choice Bis incorrect because Protista and prokaryota are not the names of domains.Choice Cis incorrect because Protista is not one of the domains.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Early cladograms were constructed by comparing structures of organisms. The cladogram on the left is based on structure and the cladogram on the right is based on comparing the DNA sequence of a particular gene.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71a6aa14-4f15-478b-a24a-ca99ed0fd98f/images/cbe839a7-5b86-466c-bb39-f4cbda23ccd1/BI0551.png)

[Source: Left: Adapted from Milinkovitch, M., Thewissen, J. (1997).Even-toed fingerprints on whale ancestry. Nature 388, (622–623).  Retrieved January 4, 2023, from https://doi.org/10.1038/41650. Copyright under open access; Right: Adapted from Masato Nikaido, Alejandro P. Rooney, Norihiro Okada. (1999, August 31).Phylogenetic relationships among cetartiodactyls based on insertions of short and long interpersed elements: Hippopotamuses are the closest extant relatives of whales. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Retrieved January 4, 2023, from https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.96.18.10261.  Copyright-free.]What is the reason that the cladogram based on the DNA sequences is a more reliable representation of the sequence of divergence among clades than the cladogram based on structures?A.\hspace{1em}Structures are not inherited when species diverge.B.\hspace{1em}DNA does not change over time while structures can change over time.C.\hspace{1em}Similar structures can be coded for by different genes in genetically distant organisms.D.\hspace{1em}There are many different structures that are coded for by the same DNA sequence.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Morphological traits, or structures, are useful for creating cladograms. However, cladograms created by comparing such traits may be inaccurate because distantly related organisms can have structures that appear similar but have different genetic bases. The appearance of similar structures with a different evolutionary basis is not evidence of relatedness, but rather is evidence of convergent evolution. So, one reason the cladogram based on the DNA sequences is more reliable than the cladogram based on structures is that similar structures can be coded for by different genes in genetically distant organisms.Choice Ais incorrect because structures are inherited when species diverge, and the inheritance of structures is beneficial for constructing cladograms.  This is because shared structures are sometimes, but not always, evidence of genetic relatedness.Choice Bis incorrect because DNA does change over time. Scientists look at sequences of changes in DNA to determine evolutionary relatedness.Choice Dis incorrect because different structures are generally coded for by different DNA sequences.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
What information can be deduced from the cladogram?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a7b55663-83dc-4b1c-8dc9-a1a4836ae09c/images/d887ade3-cdd4-4ad6-89ee-2d5616c78b8b/cladogram%20of%20primates%20i.png)

[Adapted from: Source Bockman, P. (2011, October 3).File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https:// commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]A.\hspace{1em}Lorises and Tarsiers share a common ancestor.B.\hspace{1em}Old world monkeys and New world monkeys have the same DNA sequences.C.\hspace{1em}Human and Lemur species are the same age.D.\hspace{1em}Tarsiers and Lemurs do not share a common ancestor.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:All organisms on the same cladogram share a common ancestor.Choice Ais correct.Choice Bis incorrect as old world and new world monkeys have evolutionarily split on the cladogram, so there are differences in their DNA sequence.Choice Cis incorrect as this cladogram does not show the age of the species.Choice Dis incorrect because lemurs and tarsiers are on the same cladogram so they do share the same ancestor.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
The cladogram below shows three possible evolutionary origins of the platypus (Platypus X, Y, and Z), an egg-laying mammal with webbed feet. The italicised taxa are extinct.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b1d5b447-bd27-4715-ae01-364bf736d736/images/2b9787f4-b693-44f9-8732-f9b721309317/bi0565.png)

[Sources: adapted from Celik, M.A. and Phillips, M.J. (2020).Conflict Resolution for Mesozoic Mammals: Reconciling Phylogenetic Incongruence Among Anatomical Regions. Front. Genet. 11:0651. Retrieved January 4, 2023 from https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32774343/. Copyright  under CC BY 4.0]State the taxa most closely related to marsupials.[1]Based on the taxa shown in the cladogram, deduce one reason for the difficulty in identifying the true divergence of the platypus.[1]The cladogram shown is based on morphological traits. Describeoneother type of evidence that can be used to deduce evolutionary relationships.[2]Suggestonetype of morphological evidence that could be used to provide support for Platypus Z over Platypus X as the origin of the platypus.[1]Taxonomists classify organisms according to their evolutionary origins using a hierarchical classification system.Outline the principal taxonomic ranks in the modern classification system.[2]
list.markScheme: →\ce{->}​placental mammals[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Placental mammals(✓\checkmark✓) are most closely related to marsupials. They are both members of Theria.Anyoneof the following:→\ce{->}​most species are extinct[1]→\ce{->}​must rely on fossil evidence[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Most of the speciesin the cladogramare extinct(✓\checkmark✓), so scientistsmust rely on fossils(✓\checkmark✓) of these organisms to identify relatedness and determine the divergence of the platypus.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{->}​DNA sequenceORgene sequencesORamino acid sequencesORprotein sequences[1]→\ce{->}​compare sequences for shared geneORprotein in different species[1]→\ce{->}​number of differences in sequences indicates degree of relatednessORthe more differences there are between species the more distantly related they are[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Scientists can useDNA sequences(✓\checkmark✓) to determine evolutionary relationships. For example, scientists mightcomparethe nucleotidesequence of a shared geneacross species (✓\checkmark✓). By comparing the sequences of nucleotides in the same gene, scientists can inferthe order in which the changes most likely occurred. This allows them to determine the most likelydivergence order(✓\checkmark✓) among the organisms.Anyoneof the following:→\ce{->}​identificationORcomparison of homologous structures[1]→\ce{->}​identification of vestigial structures[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Scientists couldidentify and compare homologous structures(✓\checkmark✓) in the platypus to those of other mammals. For example, if the webbed feet of the platypus are more like the feet of marsupials than the feet of ancestral species likeDocodonta, the platypus may be more closely related to Theria than it is toDocodonta.OR Alternative answerScientists couldidentify vestigial structures(✓\checkmark✓) in the platypus and other mammals. For example, if the platypus and marsupials have similar vestigial structures that are also similar to functional structures that were present in earlier groups of mammals, the platypus likely emerged afterDocodontain the evolution of mammals.Anytwoof the following:→\ce{->}​domain is the largest rank[1]→\ce{->}​the three domains are Archaea, Eubacteria, and Eukarya[1]→\ce{->}​domain Eukarya is split into kingdoms[1]→\ce{->}​from largest to smallest, kingdoms are divided into phylaORphylum, classes, orders, families, generaORgenuses, and species[1]→\ce{->}​species are sometimes divided into subspecies[1][2 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thelargest rankin the classification system is thedomain(✓\checkmark✓). There are three domains –Archaea, Eubacteria, and Eukarya(✓\checkmark✓). Thedomain Eukarya is divided into 4 kingdoms(✓\checkmark✓) – Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia. Eachkingdom is further divided, from largest to smallest into phyla, class, order, family, genus, and species(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
The image shows the skulls of a gorilla, chimpanzee, and human. What conclusion can be drawn from the anatomies of the skulls?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dae42746-c318-47a8-bb28-40949593158e/images/1dc8d91c-26ff-4b43-954b-8b30cb9b0c03/BI1522%20fig1.png)

[Source: Adapted from Zhang, K. (2015, May 1). Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved February 29, 2024.https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: The_Skulls_of_the_gorilla,chimpanzee_and_humans_-_Kaiwei_Zhang.jpg. Copyright free]A.\hspace{1em}Gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than they are to humansB.\hspace{1em}Humans are more intelligent than chimpanzees and gorillasC.\hspace{1em}Gorillas, chimpanzees and humans share a recent common ancestorD.\hspace{1em}Chimpanzees and gorillas have a diploid chromosome number of 48, whereas humans have a diploid chromosome number of 46
list.markScheme: CSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The similar anatomies of the gorilla, chimpanzee and human skull suggest they have a common ancestor;Choice Cis correct.Choice Ais incorrect, as similar anatomy is not enough to say that gorillas and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than humans due to convergent evolution.Choice Bis incorrect, as skull size is not necessarily correlated to intelligence.Choice Dis incorrect as skull size and shape do not provide any information on chromosome number.

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Which of the following isnotevidence for organisms being in the same clade?A.\hspace{1em}Chimpanzees (P. troglodytes) share 99% of their DNA with humans (H. sapiens).B.\hspace{1em}African elephants (L. africana) and manatees share a common ancestor (T. manatus).C.\hspace{1em}Bonobo  (P. paniscus) and humans (H. sapiens) both choose to play with gender specific toys.D.\hspace{1em}E. colihave a 95% similarity amino acid sequence toS. enterica.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Two organisms having similar behaviour is not evidence that they belong in the same clade soChoice Cis correct. A clade is a group of organisms that have evolved from a common ancestor, and is usually determined by similarity in amino acid and DNA sequences, thereforeChoices A,BandDcould be used as evidence for organisms to be in the same clad and are thus incorrect for this question.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: What is the relationship between the number of differences in DNA base sequences and time since divergence from a common ancestor?A.\hspace{1em}The lower the number of differences, the more recently organisms diverged from each other.B.\hspace{1em}The number of differences is equal to the number of years since the organisms diverged.C.\hspace{1em}The higher the number of differences, the more recently organisms diverged from each other.D.\hspace{1em}There is no relationship between the number of differences in DNA base sequences and time since divergence.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The number of sequence differences acts as a molecular clock, so the lower the number of differences accumulated in the DNA base sequence, the more closely related and more recently the organisms diverged from each other.Choice Ais correct.Choice Bis incorrect because the number of differences is not an exact measurement of time.Choice Cis incorrect as it’s the opposite ofChoice A.Choice Dis incorrect as there is a relationship.

list.title: Question 20
list.content: The table shows the number of differences in amino acid sequences for the Insulin-A protein, between pigs and other organisms.\hspace{3em}Organism\hspace{3em}Number of differences in amino acid sequence for Insulin-AHuman2Cow5Giraffe50Goat4Warthog1Chimpanzee10Flamingo25Which organism would be furthest from pigs in a cladogram?A.\hspace{1em}Warthogs because they have the least number of differencesB.\hspace{1em}Giraffes because they have the largest number of differencesC.\hspace{1em}Humans because they are most different physicallyD.\hspace{1em}Flamingoes because they have a different number of limbs
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Organisms with the largest differences in the amino acid sequence are the most evolutionarily diverged, so would be the furthest apart.Choice Bis correct.Choice Ais incorrect as warthogs and pigs have the least number of differences so would be the closest organisms on a cladogram.Choices CandDare incorrect because cladograms are not based on physical appearance.

list.title: Question 21
list.content: The cyanobacteriaLeptolyngbya nigrescenshas recently been reclassified asPhormidesmis nigrescens. What is a  possible reason for this?A.\hspace{1em}Observation of similar sensitivities to light between bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus and the newly classifiedPhormidesmis nigrescensB.\hspace{1em}Discovery of structural similarities of cyanobacteria to other bacteria in theLeptolyngbyagenusC.\hspace{1em}Discovery of similarities in ribosomal RNA sequences betweenPhormidesmis nigrescensand other bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenusD.\hspace{1em}New evidence thatPhormidesmis nigrescensshare a common ancestor with other cyanobacteria in theLeptolyngbyagenus
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Similarities between ribosomal RNA sequences betweenPhormidesmis nigrescensand other bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus indicates that they are likely to share a common ancestor, belong in the same genus and therefore should be reclassified.Choice Cis correct.Similarities in behaviour do not indicate thatPhormidesmis nigrescensshare a common ancestor with other bacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus;Choice Ais incorrect. To be reclassified, thePhormidesmis nigrescensshould be more similar to bacteria in the Phormidesmis genus than theLeptolyngbyagenus, also structural similarities are not grounds for reclassification;Choice Bis incorrect. To be reclassified, thePhormidesmis nigrescensshould share a common ancestor with cyanobacteria in thePhormidesmisgenus rather than theLeptolyngbyagenus;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
The image shows a cladogram for several species of hamster.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/47f20b44-acd8-4729-8737-b858aa3d4375/images/f8f32c6b-0ecc-4be9-ac60-535e09501347/BI1375.png)

[Source: Adapted from Michaplot. (2012, January 4).File: PhodopusCladogram.jpg. Wikipedia. Retrieved December 04, 2023 from URL  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 3.0]State what is represented by the letterX.[1]Other than their positions on the cladogram, explain what information indicates thatPhodopus campbelliandPhodopus sungorusare closely related.[1]Modern hamsters have small, furry ears. The common ancestor of the hamsters in the cladogram has been hypothesised to have large, furry ears. Suggest how natural selection explains these changes.[3]
list.markScheme: Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​node[1]→\ce{ -> }​the last common ancestor ofPhodopus campbelliANDPhodopus sungorus[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Letter X represents anode(✓\checkmark✓).Anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​they are from the same genusORin thePhodopusgenus[1][1 mark maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:They are in the samegenus(✓\checkmark✓).Anyfthreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​natural selection is the process by which species change over time in response to changes in the environmentORcompetition between organisms in order for species to survive[1]→\ce{ -> }​random mutation resulted in new allele for smaller ears[1]→\ce{ -> }​increases genetic variationORdiversity within the  population[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutationORnew alleleORallele for smaller ears proved beneficialORled to greater chance of survival[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased reproductive successORmore chance of having offspringORhaving more offspring[1]→\ce{ -> }​the offspring inherited the allele for smaller earsORbeneficial alleles passed onto next generation[1]→\ce{ -> }​over many generations the allele for shorter ears increased in frequency in the populationORsmall-eared hamsters increased in number in the population[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Many years ago,random mutationsoccurred in some hamsters that gave themnew allelesfor smaller ears (✓\checkmark✓), the allele for smaller ears gave those hamsters asurvival advantage(✓\checkmark✓). These hamsters weremore likelyto haveoffspring(✓\checkmark✓), and thebeneficial allelefor small ears waspassed ontotheoffspring(✓\checkmark✓). Overmany generations, there was anincreasein the number of hamsters withsmaller earsand adecreasein the number of hamsters withlarger ears(✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
The following image shows a member of theScrophulariaceae(figwort) family drawn in 1774. Although this family was once among the largest groups of flowering plants, it has since been reclassified and is now less than half of its former size. Which of the following explains why reclassification of taxonomic groups may be required?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c908cc5-d161-4aae-aebd-4022e07a9452/images/faca6029-51b6-4e7b-9dc9-1f94775fc7d7/BI1390.png)

[Source: Bouchard, M. (1774).Figwort (Scrophularia sp): flowering stem with separate flower. Look and Learn. Retrieved December 30, 2023, from https://www.lookandlearn.com/history-images/YW042762VEL/Figwort-Scrophularia-sp-flowering-stem-with-separate-flower. Copyright BY CC 4.0]A.\hspace{1em}Genomic sequencingB.\hspace{1em}Improvements in dichotomous keysC.\hspace{1em}Genetically modified speciesD.\hspace{1em}Discovery of new species
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When the taxonomic system was developed, species were largely classified according to physical similarities. With the discovery of DNA and gene sequencing techniques, it became possible to compare the genomes of organisms. Genomic data allows the evolutionary relationships between organisms to be determined much more accurately and thus can lead to the reclassification of some taxa.Choice Ais correct.Choice Bis incorrect because dichotomous keys are used to identify organisms based on observable characteristics, not for reclassifying taxonomic groups.Choice Cis incorrect because genetic modification is when the genetic material of an organism has been altered through human intervention, however, this does not lead to the reclassification of species.Choice Dis incorrect since the discovery of a new species should not affect previously classified organisms, especially if genome sequencing is used as the primary means of classification.

list.title: Question 24
list.content: Which of the following wouldnotbe a reason for reclassification?A.\hspace{1em}Discovery of a new speciesB.\hspace{1em}Evidence for a common ancestorC.\hspace{1em}Evidence of similar bone structuresD.\hspace{1em}Observation of different behaviours
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because behaviours do not indicate common ancestry.Choice Bis incorrect because natural classification is based on common ancestry so evidence for a common ancestor can lead to reclassification.Choice Ais incorrect because the discovery of a new species may provide evidence of a common ancestor and lead to reclassification.Choice Cis incorrect because evidence of similar bone structures may be part of the evidence for a common ancestor and lead to an organism being reclassified.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: Outline how mitochondrial DNA can be used to construct a cladogram.[4]Explain why organisms classified in the past may be reclassified.[4]Compare and contrast cladograms made using molecular evidence and structural evidence.[7]
list.markScheme: Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​mitochondrial DNA from different organisms can be sequenced[1]→\ce{ -> }​mutations occur at a roughly constant rateORcan act as a molecular clock[1]→\ce{ -> }​the lower the number of differences in the base sequence between organisms, the more closely related the organisms are[1]→\ce{ -> }​the number of differences in the base sequence can be used to determine how long ago species diverged from a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​which can be used to deduce where the nodes are on cladograms[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Sections of mitochondrial DNA fromdifferent organisms can be sequenced(✓\checkmark✓), which allows scientists to observe differences in the base sequence. Thelower the number of differencesin the base sequence between organisms, themore closely relatedthe organisms are (✓\checkmark✓). Thenumber of differencesin the sequence of mitochondrial DNA can also be used to determinehow long ago species divergedfrom a common ancestor (✓\checkmark✓), which can be used to deduceposition of nodeson cladograms (✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​organisms (used to be) classified based on shared anatomical characteristicsORstructuresORphysical features[1]→\ce{ -> }​shared anatomical characteristicsORstructuresORphysical features may be analogousORnot due to common ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​analogous structures as a result of convergent evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms (are now) classified using amino acidORDNA sequences[1]→\ce{ -> }​increased accuracyORreliability of cladograms made using DNAORamino acid sequences[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:In the past, organisms were classified based on sharedphysical features(✓\checkmark✓), howeverphysical features could be analogousand therefore not the result of common ancestry (✓\checkmark✓). Cladograms which are constructed usingDNA or amino acid sequences(✓\checkmark✓) are morereliable(✓\checkmark✓) and can highlight new evolutionary relationships which would lead to organisms potentially being reclassified.Anysevenof the following:→\ce{ -> }​BOTHseek to demonstrateORdeduce evolutionary relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain a rootORancestor common to all organisms within the cladogram[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain nodesORpoints at which species diverged from one another[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcontain cladesORan ancestor and all of its evolutionary descendants[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHcan contain outgroupsORthe most distantly related species[1]→\ce{ -> }​species inBOTHmay be reclassified (in response to new evidence)[1]→\ce{ -> }​species organised based on anatomical structuresORphysical characteristicsWHEREASspecies are organised based on amino acidORDNA sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​in the past cladograms were constructed using similarities in physical featuresWHEREASnow DNAORamino acid sequences are used[1]→\ce{ -> }​molecular evidenceORDNA sequencesORamino sequences more reliableORaccurate than structural evidenceORphysical characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​analogous structures can be an issue in cladograms made using structural similaritiesBUTnot in cladograms using molecular evidenceORDNAORamino acid sequences[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladograms made using structural evidence require less technologyCOMPAREDto cladograms using molecular evidenceORDNA or amino acid sequences[1][7 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Cladograms which are made using structural evidence and those made using molecular evidence have several things in common, for example,both havefeatures such as aroot(✓\checkmark✓),nodes(✓\checkmark✓) andclades(✓\checkmark✓), theybothalso attempt to showevolutionary relationshipsbetween species (✓\checkmark✓). However there are some differences in these cladograms. In cladograms made using structural evidence, thephysical characteristicsof species are used to organise them into groups, but in cladograms using molecular evidence, scientists use the number of differences in the DNA oramino acid sequence(✓\checkmark✓), which is known to be the morereliable(✓\checkmark✓) method and is more commonly used now, compared to structural features being used more in thepast(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 26
list.content: Explain four properties of water that make it important in supporting life on Earth.[4]Describe the recent methods used to reclassify plant groups, such as the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae), based on cladistic evidence.[4]Explain how the structure of synovial joints is adapted for movement and why this influences the range of motion.[7]
list.markScheme: anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​solvent so enables reactions to occurORtransport of substances[1]→\ce{ -> }​large latent heat of vaporisationORA large amount of energy is needed to evaporate water so provides a cooling effect[1]→\ce{ -> }​high specific heat capacityORwater absorbsORretains heat without large changes in temperature, providing thermal stability in aquatic environmentsORorganisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​cohesionORhydrogen bonding between water molecules aids water transport in plantsORcreates surface tension, enabling small organismsORinsects to move on water[1]→\ce{ -> }​adhesionORwater molecules stick to other polar surfaces, supporting capillary action in plants[1]→\ce{ -> }​ice floatsORice is less dense than liquid waterORwater’s density decreases as it cools below 4°\degree°C insulating aquatic ecosystems in cold climatesORhelping aquatic life survive in cold conditions[1]→\ce{ -> }​water is transparent, allowing light to penetrate for photosynthesis in aquatic plantsORalgaeORenables visibility in aquatic environments[1]→\ce{ -> }​provides buoyancy, enabling aquatic organisms to remain suspendedORsupports the body structure of soft-bodied aquatic organisms[1]→\ce{ -> }​amphoteric natureORcan act as both an acid and a base, maintaining pH balance in biological systems[1]→\ce{ -> }​non-compressible helps maintain cell turgorORstructure of plant cells[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Water has ahigh specific heat capacitywhich allows it toabsorbandretain heat, providingthermal stabilityforaquatic environmentsandliving organisms(✓\checkmark✓). It is also auniversal solventdue to itspolarity, enabling it todissolve ionsandorganic moleculesfortransportandbiochemical reactions(✓\checkmark✓). Thecohesionbetween water moleculessupportsthetransport of waterinplantsthrough thexylem, whilesurface tensionallowssmall organisms, like insects, tomove on water(✓\checkmark✓).Ice is less densethan liquid water, which ensures itfloatsandinsulates aquatic ecosystemsincold environments, protecting life below (✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​early classification was based on morphologyORgrouped plants based on visible traits[1]→\ce{ -> }​early classification often led to misclassification due to convergent evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​recent cladistics relies on molecular data,ORDNAORRNA nucleotideORamino acid sequencingORsequence comparisons[1]→\ce{ -> }​molecular clock estimates divergence timesORDNA mutations occur at a relatively constant rate, allowing estimation of when species diverged from a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​phylogenetic tree construction from genetic data[1]→\ce{ -> }​common derived characteristics define clades[1]→\ce{ -> }​number of differences in genetic sequences indicates evolutionary distance from a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​use of outgroups to determine which traits are homologousORancestralORwhich traits are analogousORresult from convergent evolution[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladistics has led to reclassification of plant familiesORfigwort familyORScrophulariaceaewas reclassified after genetic analysis revealed it contained multiple unrelated lineages[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Earlyplantclassificationwas based onmorphology, grouping plants byvisible traitssuch as leaf and flower structure  (✓\checkmark✓). However, this often led tomisclassificationdue toconvergent evolution, whereunrelated speciesdevelopedsimilar features(✓\checkmark✓).Modern cladisticsnow relies onDNA sequencingtoanalyse genetic differencesand determineevolutionary relationships(✓\checkmark✓). Themolecular clockhelpsestimate divergence times, asmutationsaccumulate at arelatively constant rate(✓\checkmark✓). This has led to thereclassificationofplant families, such as thefigwort family(Scrophulariaceae), aftergenetic analysisrevealedmultiple unrelated lineages(✓\checkmark✓).anysevenof the following(must contain at leasttwofrom each section to gain full marks):how the structure of a synovial joint allows movement→\ce{ -> }​joint cavity filled with synovial fluid,WHICHreduces frictionORallows smooth movementORnourishes the cartilageORlubricates the joint[1]→\ce{ -> }​articulating surfaces of bones are covered by cartilageWHICHreduces frictionORcushions the jointORprevents bone-to-bone contact[1]→\ce{ -> }​ligaments provide stability by connecting bonesANDpreventing excessive or harmful movement[1]→\ce{ -> }​synovial membrane produces synovial fluid[1]→\ce{ -> }​capsuleORcapsular ligament seals the jointANDprovides additional stability while allowing movement[1]→\ce{ -> }​bones provide a firm anchorage for musclesANDact as levers to amplify movement[1]→\ce{ -> }​tendons attach muscles to bones, enabling movement when muscles contract[1]factors that influence the range of motion→\ce{ -> }​shape of the articulating surfaces determines the range of movement possible[1]→\ce{ -> }​joint capsuleORligaments - restrict movement to prevent injury, limiting excessive range while allowing flexibility[1]→\ce{ -> }​hinge joints only allow movement in one plane flexionANDextension[1]→\ce{ -> }​ball and socket joints allow protractionANDretractionORabductionANDadductionORrotation[1]→\ce{ -> }​range of motion is influenced by the shape and fit of the bones at the joint[1]→\ce{ -> }​the flexibility and strength of surrounding ligaments affect how far a joint can move without injury[1]→\ce{ -> }​damage to cartilage reduces range of movement due to painORfriction[1]→\ce{ -> }​strongerORmore flexible muscles can support a greater range of motion[1][7 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Synovial joints facilitate movement through their unique structure. Articulatingbonesare covered withcartilagetoreduce friction(✓\checkmark✓), andsynovial fluidwithin thejoint cavity lubricatesthe joint (✓\checkmark✓).Ligaments stabilizethe joint by connecting the bones (✓\checkmark✓), whiletendons transmit forcesfrommusclestobones, as they areattached to both(✓\checkmark✓). Theshapeof the joint, such as ball-and-socket or hinge types, determines thetypesofmovementspossible (✓\checkmark✓). Therangeofmotionis influenced by thefit of the bones(✓\checkmark✓), theflexibilityofligaments(✓\checkmark✓), and thestrengthofsurrounding muscles(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 27
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:First, compare the sequences of the different organisms to the human sequence:OrganismAmino acid sequence for HBA1Number of differences from humanHumanAQVKGHGKKVADAL0 (reference)SharkPSIKAHGAKVVTAL6DuckAQIKAHGKKVAAAL3BatAQVKGHGKKVGDAL1CobraKDIIHQGEKVGKAL9Then rank the organisms by similarity in amino acid sequences for HBA1 to humans:Most similar is the bat, then the duck, then the shark, and then the one with the least similar sequence is the cobraThe correct cladogram isChoice Das it reflects this hierarchy.In real life, cobra (a reptile) and human (a mammal) are both amniotes, sharing a more recent common ancestor than either does with shark, which is a cartilaginous fish. The observed pattern in the table, where the shark appears more similar to humans than the cobra based on HBA1 sequences, is an artefact of analysing a single gene and is not reflective of the broader evolutionary relationship.Choices A, B, andCare incorrect because they do not follow the relationship order suggested by the amino acid differences in the table.

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
A  biology class was given the following information:I.W, X, YandZare all closely related animal species.II.g, WandYall evolved from animal speciesX.III.Speciesgis an extinct recent common ancestor ofWandY.IV.Animal speciesZis the least related to the others, with extinct specieshserving as its most recent phylogenetic connection to the others.Below are cladograms drawn by four different students to represent the evolutionary relationships described.Which student drew the cladogram correctly?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/26760cb4-c948-4999-8142-62356a5904b4/images/61ddfb74-bb4b-4911-b1e2-92fbf65411c6/4%20cladograms%20together.png)

[©Revision Village 2024]
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Animal speciesZneeds to be in a different clade toWandYas it is the least closely related. However,Zis still linked toWandYvia animal speciesh.WandYare linked via a recent common ancestor,g, andW, Yandgare all linked via animal speciesX. This makes studentChoice Bcorrect.
The cladogram drawn by student A is incorrect in many ways, including placing extinct specieshas the most distantly related species ofWandY, and placingZas the common ancestor connecting all the other species.Choice Ais, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.The cladogram drawn by student C is incorrect in several places, including puttinghas the most recent extinct ancestor ofWandXand puttinggas the common ancestor connecting all the other species.Choice Cis, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.The cladogram drawn by student D  incorrectly groupsWandXtogether after their divergence from the extinct species h. The cladogram incorrectly placesgas the common ancestor of all the other species.Choice Dis, therefore, not the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 29
list.content: The DNA sequence from the same section of DNA but from two different organisms is shown in the table below.Which organisms are most likely to have diverged from each other most recently?Sequence 1Sequence 2\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}ATCGGGTCGCTTTCTCGATCCGGTCGCTTTGTCG\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}TCGCGCGTAAATCGATGTCCCGCGTCAATCGTTA\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}ATCGGGTGTGTCATATGATCGCGTGTCTCATCTG\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}TGTCATCATCCCGTACTGTGTCATCATCGGCATGAC
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because the two sequences have the smallest number of differences between them, only two, therefore they are the most closely related.Choices B,CandDare incorrect, as there are more than 2 differences between the two sequences, 4, 3 and 8, respectively.

list.title: Question 30
list.content: Genetic variation is the root of phenotypic diversity between and within species.Phenotypic expression relies on the genome and proteome. Outline the differences between the genome and the proteome[3]While genetic variations can be beneficial, others can lead to detrimental health conditions, such as diabetes. Compare and contrast Type I and Type II diabetes.[4]Describe the approaches used to classify different species.[8]
list.markScheme: Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​genome is the complete set of genetic material present in an organismORincludes all the genes, regulatory elements and non-coding regions of the genetic material of an organismWHEREASproteome is the entire set of proteins producedORexpressed by a cell, tissue, or organism at a specific time under defined conditions[1]→\ce{ -> }​genome composed of DNA nucleotidesWHEREASproteome composed of amino acids[1]→\ce{ -> }​genome stores genetic informationORis a template for the synthesis of proteomeWHEREASproteome carries out the functions of the organismORis involved in cellular processes[1]→\ce{ -> }​genome relatively stable over timeWHEREASproteome is highly dynamicORproteome constantly changing in response to cellular needsORenvironmentORinternal signals[1]→\ce{ -> }​size of genome is relatively constant within a speciesWHEREASproteome can be much largerORmore diverse than the genome due to alternative splicing, post-translational modifications, and protein-protein interactions[1][3 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Thegenomeis thecomplete set of genetic materialpresent in an organism, includingallthegenes, regulatory elementsandnon-coding regions, whereas theproteomeis theentire setofproteinsproduced by acell, tissue,ororganismat a specific time under defined conditions (✓\checkmark✓). Thegenomeis made up ofnucleotides, whereas theproteomeis composed ofamino acids(✓\checkmark✓). Functionally, thegenomeacts as a source of geneticinstructions, providing the information necessary for development and regulation, while theproteomeactivelyparticipatesincellular processes(✓\checkmark✓) based on these instructions. Thegenomeis relativelystablewith occasional genetic variations, whereas theproteomeis highlydynamic, responding to environmental factors (✓\checkmark✓).Anyfourof the following (AT LEAST ONEsimilarity andAT LEAST ONEdifference must be given):→\ce{ -> }​BOTHTypes of diabetes affect blood glucose concentrationORaffect the body’s ability to control blood glucose concentration[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHtypes of diabetes cause health complications if blood glucose concentration is not controlled[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I is an autoimmune diseaseWHEREASType II is linked to geneticsORlifestyleORageing[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes is caused when the beta cells are destroyed by the immune system and do not secrete enough insulinWHEREASType II diabetes is caused when body cells become insensitiveORresistant to insulin[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes usually begins in childhoodWHEREASType II diabetes usually begins in adulthood[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes cannot be controlled by lifestyle changesWHEREASType II diabetes can often be controlled by lifestyle changes[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes requires frequent measurement of blood glucose concentrationWHEREASType II diabetes does not require frequent measurement of blood glucose concentration[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I diabetes requires insulin injections from startWHEREASType II diabetes is only treated with insulin if the disease progresses[1]→\ce{ -> }​Type I tends to be diagnosed at early ageWHEREASType II tends to be diagnosed in older people[1][4 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:BothType I and Type II diabetesdisrupttheregulationofnormal blood glucose concentration(✓\checkmark✓).Type I diabetesis anautoimmune diseasewhere theimmune system destroys beta cells in the pancreas, resulting in alack of insulinproduction. The causes ofType II diabetesaremultifactorial, includinggenetics, lifestyleandageing(✓\checkmark✓), and it manifests when bodycellsbecomeresistant to insulin(✓\checkmark✓).Type I diabetesrequiresfrequent measurement of blood glucoseconcentration, whereasType II diabetesdoesnot usually requirefrequent measurements of blood glucose concentration (✓\checkmark✓).Type Idiabetes requires lifelonginsulin injections, whereasType IIdiabetes only requiresinsulininjections if thecondition progresses(✓\checkmark✓).Anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​classification is used to organise organisms into groups[1]→\ce{ -> }​binomial nomenclatureORbinomial system used to name organismsORname is genus and species[1]→\ce{ -> }​allows communication and understanding between scientists all around the world[1]→\ce{ -> }​there are three domains of life[1]→\ce{ -> }​a species is the smallest unit of classification[1]→\ce{ -> }​hierarchy is used to group speciesORthe taxa are arranged in order of decreasing group size: domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species[1]→\ce{ -> }​morphologicalORartificial classification is based on physical characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​morphology can lead to errorsORanalogous structures can mislead classification[1]→\ce{ -> }​biochemical classification analyses molecular componentsORproteinsORDNAORRNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​base sequences in nucleic acidsORamino acid sequences of proteins are analysed[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladistics is based on shared characteristics traced to most recent common ancestorORcladogram is a visual representation of how species are evolutionarily related, with a node representing a common ancestor[1]→\ce{ -> }​modern approach combines evidenceORuses all types of classificationORuses morphology, biochemistry and genetics[1]→\ce{ -> }​natural classification groups organisms based on evolutionary history[1]→\ce{ -> }​classification includes fossils[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms with a recent common ancestor are classified more closely together[1]→\ce{ -> }​species in the same genus share many characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​organisms can be reclassified when new evidence is found[1]→\ce{ -> }​natural classification allows scientists to predict characteristics of species within a group[1][8 marks maximum]Sample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Classification is the process oforganising organismsinto appropriate categories orgroupsbased on theirshared characteristics(✓\checkmark✓). Scientists usebinomial nomenclatureto assigneach organisma unique two-part name made up of thegenusandspecies(✓\checkmark✓), facilitatingglobal scientific communication(✓\checkmark✓). Organisms are traditionally classifiedhierarchically, starting with the broadest category, thedomain, then working downwards -kingdom, phylum, class, order, family genus, species(✓\checkmark✓) (which can then be split into sub-species).Traditional, artificial, classification has been based onphysical traits. However, thismorphologicalapproach (✓\checkmark✓) can bemisleadingdue toanalogous structures(✓\checkmark✓).Modernclassification integratesmorphological, biochemical, andgeneticinformation, (✓\checkmark✓).Biochemicalclassification examines themolecular componentsof organisms, including thesequencesofbasesofDNAandamino acidsofproteins(✓\checkmark✓).Cladisticsis based onshared characteristicstraced to themost recent common ancestor, and these relationships can be represented visually oncladograms(✓\checkmark✓). Asnew data emerges, reclassificationmay occur (✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
The diagrams below show two cladograms for primates. One cladogram was made using data from DNA sequences and the other using amino acid sequences.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d834264a-48ae-474c-af53-c7ed003a94e8/images/d839b234-e401-4a51-ae04-32fd9b023985/BI0272.png)

[Source: Adapted from Bockman, P. (2011, October 3).File: Primate cladogram.jpg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 14, 2022, from https: //commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Primate_cladogram.jpg CC-BY-SA-3.0]Identify the organism(s) most closely related to humans in the cladogram based on…DNAsequences[1]amino acidsequences[1]Describe the advantage of using DNA sequences to construct cladograms compared to amino acid sequences.[2]Suggest why cladograms made using physical features are not reliable predictors of phylogenetic relationships.[2]
list.markScheme: →\ce{ -> }​apes[1][1 mark maximum]→\ce{ -> }​old world monkeysANDnew world monkeys[1][1 mark maximum]Anytwoof the following:→\ce{ -> }​the nucleotide sequence of a gene contains more information than the amino acid sequence of the corresponding polypeptides[1]→\ce{ -> }​silent mutations alter the DNA sequence but do not affect the amino acid sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​degeneracy in the genetic code means a mutation does not necessarily change the amino acid sequence[1]→\ce{ -> }​greater information can be obtained by DNA sequence analysis because variability in both the coding and non-coding regions of the genome can be examined[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA samples can be easily sequencedORDNA is cheaper to sequenceORDNA sequencing yields more data whereas the approach to sequencing of proteins varies with type of protein[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA sequence can be used to establish amino acid sequence, but not the other way around[1][2 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Using DNA sequences to construct cladograms is advantageous because due to the existence ofcoding and non-coding regions(✓\checkmark✓) of DNA,more information(✓\checkmark✓) is held in the nucleotide sequence than the amino acid sequence . Also mutations may occur in the DNA which do not show up in the amino acid sequence due to thedegenerative code(✓\checkmark✓) leading tosilent mutations(✓\checkmark✓).Any two  of the following:→\ce{ -> }​adaptive radiation can result in closely related species showing very different structural features[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolution means that distantly related organisms may show very similar structural features[1]→\ce{ -> }​analogous structures are derived through separate evolutionary pathways and are not indicators of evolutionary relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that some classification of organisms based on shared structural features was incorrect[1][2 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Cladograms are no longer based on structural features due to the presence ofanalogous structures, which are the result ofconvergent evolution(✓\checkmark✓) and so arenot indicators of evolutionary relationships(✓\checkmark✓). DNA and amino acid analysis have shown that many cladograms based solely onshared structural featuresare incorrect (✓\checkmark✓).

list.title: Question 32
list.content: Which feature of Archaea helped biologists to classify them in a separate domain from other prokaryotes?A.\hspace{1em}The presence of a cell wallB.\hspace{1em}The frequency of introns in the genomeC.\hspace{1em}The presence of linear chromosomesD.\hspace{1em}The difference in structure of membrane phospholipids
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The rRNA sequencing by Carl Woese (1977) revealed that Eubacteria and Archaea are fundamentally different at a molecular level, including differences in membrane lipid structure.
Archaea have membrane phospholipids consisting of the L-glycerol in the phosphate group. Eubacteria, and Eukarya, have D-glycerol in the phosphate groups of their phospholipids.Choice Dis, therefore, correct.Choice Ais incorrect because cell walls are present in both domains (Archaea and Eubacteria), although made of different polymers.Choice Bis incorrect because introns (non-coding regions of DNA) are found in Eukaryota only, not in either of the prokaryote domains.Choice Cis incorrect because linear chromosomes are found in Eukaryota only, not in either of the prokaryote domains. The genomes of Archaea and Eubacteria are made of circular DNA.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
Organisms may be reclassified using evidence from cladistics. Cladogram 1, based on DNA comparisons of several species, represents the historical view of relationships among arachnids. Cladogram 2, based on DNA comparisons of many more species than Cladogram 1, challenges the historical view.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f58f8ff-0c6d-45ec-b83b-b630124d062a/images/facf56c0-5f41-4a9d-9e82-077c9b0d142f/BI0510.png)

[Source: Adapted from Ballesteros, J.A., Santibáñez-López, C.E., Baker, C.M.,  Benavides, L.R., Cunha T.J., Gainett, G., Ontano A.Z., Setton, E.V.W, Arango, C.P., Gavish-Regev, E., Harvey, M.S., Wheeler, W.C., Hormiga, G., Giribet, G., & Sharma, P.P. (2022).Comprehensive Species Sampling and Sophisticated Algorithmic Approaches Refute the Monophyly of Arachnida. Molecular Biology and Evolution, Volume 39, Issue 2, Retrieved March 15, 2022, from https://doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msac021. Copyright under CC BY 4.0]What is suggested by Cladogram 2 that is not suggested by Cladogram 1?A.\hspace{1em}Horseshoe crabs are a sister group of arachnids.B.\hspace{1em}Horseshoe crabs are a group within arachnids.C.\hspace{1em}Sea spiders are an ancestor of arachnids.D.\hspace{1em}Sea spiders are not an ancestor of horseshoe crabs.
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Both cladograms show the relationships among arachnids and organisms related to arachnids. Cladogram 1 shows sea spiders and horseshoe crabs as related to, but not members, of the arachnids. Horseshoe crabs therefore form a sister group to the arachnids (A sister group is the closest relative to a given unit in a cladogram). Cladogram 2 shows horseshoe crabs as a group within the arachnids.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f58f8ff-0c6d-45ec-b83b-b630124d062a/images/fc803d09-abaa-4f4e-bdb8-31f8b7aab5c1/BI0510A.png)

So, Cladogram 2 indicates that horseshoe crabs are a group within the arachnids, a relationship not indicated by Cladogram 1.Cladogram 1, not Cladogram 2, indicates that horseshoe crabs are a sister group of arachnids (Choice A). Both cladograms show that sea spiders were an ancestor of arachnids (Choices CandD).

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
Natural classification is used to group organisms with common ancestry together, based on similarities and shared characteristics. All organisms can be classified into one of the three domains.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dec0eb78-75d9-46b9-8d5b-dd3556815829/images/5ca392ca-aa33-406f-ace3-eb2621e12545/BI0260.png)

[ © Revision Village 2022]List three characteristics of Eubacteria.[3]Distinguish between archaeans and eukaryotes.[1]Outline how a case study like the reclassification of the figwort family (Scrophulariaceae) demonstrates the limitations of morphology-based taxonomy.[4]
list.markScheme: anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​unicellular[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryoticORno true nucleusORno membrane-bound organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​single chromosome[1]→\ce{ -> }​DNA is a loop[1]→\ce{ -> }​proteins associated with DNA may or may not be present[1]→\ce{ -> }​70S ribosomes[1]→\ce{ -> }​cell wall made of peptidoglycan[1][3 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Eubacteria are organisms that areunicellular(✓\checkmark✓) and have no true nucleus. They havea single chromosome(✓\checkmark✓) that is aloop(✓\checkmark✓) andhistone proteins may or may not be present(✓\checkmark✓). Theribosomes of Eubacteria are 70S(✓\checkmark✓) and theircell walls are made of peptidoglycan(✓\checkmark✓).anyoneof the following:→\ce{ -> }​Archaea do not have membrane-bound organellesWHEREASEukaryota do have membrane-bound organelles[1]→\ce{ -> }​Archaea do not have a nucleusWHEREASEukaryota do have a nucleus[1]→\ce{ -> }​Archaea have circular chromosomesWHEREASEukaryota have linear chromosomes[1][1 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Archaeahave circular chromosomesbut Eukaryotahave linear chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓). Archaeado not have a nucleusbut Eukaryota do (✓\checkmark✓).anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​morphology-based taxonomy relies on physical similarities in structuress[1]→\ce{ -> }​similarities used in morphology-based classification may result from convergent evolution, not common ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​convergent evolution produces analogous structures that look similar but evolved independently[1]→\ce{ -> }​the figwort familyORScrophulariaceaewas originally grouped based on morphological traits[1]→\ce{ -> }​molecular and cladistic analyses showed that some species classified in the figwort family were more closely related to species in other families[1]→\ce{ -> }​led to the reclassification of many species into different families based on genetic evidence[1]→\ce{ -> }​case study shows that relying only on morphology can mislead taxonomy because of homoplasy OR similar traits not due to common ancestry[1]→\ce{ -> }​cladistics, using DNAORmolecular data, provides a more objective and accurate method for determining evolutionary relationships[1]→\ce{ -> }​reclassification highlights how scientific classifications are hypotheses that can be falsified or revised with new evidence[1][4 marks maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:The figwort family wasoriginally classifiedbased onmorphological traits, such asflower shape(✓\checkmark✓). However,DNA sequencingandcladistic analysisshowed thatsome specieswere more closely related to plants in other families,not sharingarecent common ancestorwith thefigworts(✓\checkmark✓). This finding demonstrated that thesimilarities in structureresulted fromconvergent evolution, whereunrelated speciesdevelopsimilar traitsindependently (✓\checkmark✓). Therefore,relying solelyonmorphologycan bemisleading in classification, highlighting the importance ofmolecular dataformore accurateevolutionary relationships (✓\checkmark✓).
